pages.text: Hypocausts are antique central heating systems. In a hypocaust system, heat comes from a central block (firebox) and spreads to a relatively large area.
$(l:intro/kitchen_materials)Kitchen materials$(/l) can be used to build hypocausts, except mud-and-drystone, since it could be unstable and is not waterproof.

When building a hypocaust system, the central firebox and caliducts should be connected horizontally, and the firebox should be put on a heat source, like $(l:intro/stove)stoves$(/l) or $(l:worldgen/volcanic_fumarole)fumarole vent$(/l). A hypocaust system can be heated by multiple fireboxes, but the heat reaches will not add up.

Heated hypocaust system would in turn heat water above it, making it bath water with steam particles. When inside bath water, you can gain experience gradually, but at a very slow speed. A firebox can heat up a 9x9 area surrounding it.
An example of a hypocaust-heated bath.
